thread.title: Panda won't let zoo worker go as it clings to his legs | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Panda won't let zoo worker go as it clings to his legs | Daily Mail Online

author: Harriet Mallinson For Mailonline
title: Panda won't let zoo worker go as it clings to his legs | Daily Mail Online
text: Share this article Share The clip was uploaded to YouTube channel, iPanda - a live panda-cam operated jointly by China Network Television and Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding. 'That's a job I wouldn't mind going to every day,' one viewer cooed, while another wrote, 'OMG! I would've stop doing what I'm doing to just play with that loaded of sweetness!!' Attempts to place the animal higher up and further away fail too as the determined mammal finds a way each time to navigate a route down and back to the object of his affections The clip was uploaded to YouTube channel, iPanda - a live panda-cam operated jointly by China Network Television and Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding 'That's a job I wouldn't mind going to every day,' one viewer cooed, while another wrote, 'OMG! I would've stop doing what I'm doing to just play with that loaded of sweetness!!' iPanda.com was launched in 2013 to capture all the cute moments of the Chengdu pandas’ lives, from every angle Pandas live in mountain forests, and as typically solitary creatures are usually quite content to entertain themselves iPanda.com was launched in 2013 to capture all the cute moments of the Chengdu pandas’ lives, from every angle. It has turned many of the creatures into viral stars as the animals have been seen playing, fighting and mating. It hopes to raise awareness of China’s national animal, an endangered species with less than 2,000 left in the wild. Pandas live in mountain forests, and as typically solitary creatures are usually quite content to entertain themselves. SIX FACTS YOU DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT GIANT PANDAS It's estimated that there are around 1,600 Giant Pandas in the wild. There are 300 in zoos and breeding centres around the world. It's unsure how long Giant Pandas live in the wild. However Chinese scientists reported zoo pandas as old as 35. A wild panda's diet is 99 percent bamboo while the remaining one percent is usually small rodents. Giant Pandas need to consume around 20 to 40 pounds of bamboo each day to get the nutrients they need. On all four legs, Giant Pandas stand at around three to four feet tall. Cubs do not open their eyes until they are six to eight weeks of age and are not mobile until three months. Source: Smithsonian National Zoological Park Share or comment on this article 9
